Question: COM-001 - In which situations should a pilot use blind transmissions?
Option A: When no radio communication can be established with the appropriate aeronautical station, but when evidence exists that transmissions are received at that ground unit
Option B: When a pilot has flown into cloud or fog unintentionally and therefore would like to request navigational assistance from a ground unit
Option C: When a transmission containing important navigational or technical information is to be sent to several stations at the same time
Option D: When the traffic situation at an airport allows the transmission of information which does not need to be acknowledged by the ground station
Answer: When no radio communication can be established with the appropriate aeronautical station, but when evidence exists that transmissions are received at that ground unit

Question: COM-002 - Leaving a control frequency (except when reaching the final parking position)...

COM-021 - Distress messages are messages...
Option A: concerning the safety of an aircraft, a watercraft or some other vehicle or person in sight.
Option B: sent by a pilot or an aircraft operating agency which have an imminent meaning for aircraft in flight.
Option C: concerning aircraft and their passengers which face a grave and imminent threat and require immediate assistance.
Option D: concerning the operation or maintenance of facilities which are important for the safety and regularity of flight operations.
Answer: concerning aircraft and their passengers which face a grave and imminent threat and require immediate assistance.

Question: COM-022 - Urgency messages are messages...
Option A: concerning aircraft and their passengers which face a grave and imminent threat and require immediate assistance.
Option B: concerning the safety of an aircraft, a watercraft or some other vehicle or person in sight.
Option C: concerning the operation or maintenance of facilities essential for the safety or regularity of aircraft operation.
Option D: sent by a pilot or an aircraft operating agency which have an imminent meaning for aircraft in flight.
Answer: concerning the safety of an aircraft, a watercraft or some other vehicle or person in sight.

Question: COM-023 - Regularity messages are messages...
Option A: concerning the safety of an aircraft, a watercraft or some other vehicle or person in sight.
Option B: concerning aircraft and their passengers which face a grave and imminent threat and require immediate assistance.
Option C: sent by an aircraft operating agency or an aircraft of immediate concern to an aircraft in flight.
Option D: concerning the operation or maintenance of facilities essential for the safety or regularity of aircraft operation.
Answer: concerning the operation or maintenance of facilities essential for the safety or regularity of aircraft operation.

Question: COM-033 - What is the meaning of the phrase "Roger"?
Option A: Permission for proposed action is granted
Option B: I understand your message and will comply with it
Option C: I have received all of your last transmission
Option D: An error has been made in this transmission. The correct version is...
Answer: I have received all of your last transmission

Question: COM-034 - What is the meaning of the phrase "Correction"?
Option A: Permission for proposed action is granted
Option B: An error has been made in this transmission. The correct version is...
Option C: I have received all of your last transmission
Option D: I understand your message and will comply with it
Answer: An error has been made in this transmission. The correct version is...

Question: COM-035 - What is the meaning of the phrase "Approved"?
Option B: I understand your message and will comply with it
Option C: Permission for proposed action is granted
Option D: An error has been made in this transmission. The correct version is...
Answer: Permission for proposed action is granted

COM-074 - What is the correct course of action when experiencing a radio failure in class D airspace?
Option A: The flight has to be continued above 5000 feet complying with VFR flight rules or the airspace has to be left by the shortest route
Option B: The flight has to be continued according to the last clearance complying with VFR rules or the airspace has to be left by the shortest route
Option C: The flight has to be continued above 5000 feet complying with VFR flight rules or the airspace has to be left using a standard routing
Option D: The flight has to be continued according to the last clearance complying with VFR flight rules or the airspace has to be left using a standard routing
Answer: The flight has to be continued according to the last clearance complying with VFR rules or the airspace has to be left by the shortest route

COM-077 - Urgency messages are defined as...
Option A: messages concerning urgent spare parts which are needed for a continuation of flight and which need to be ordered in advance.
Option B: messages concerning the safety of an aircraft, a watercraft or some other vehicle or person in sight.
Option C: information concerning the apron personell and which imply an imminent danger to landing aircraft.
Option D: messages concerning aircraft and their passengers which face a grave and imminent threat and require immediate assistance.
Answer: messages concerning the safety of an aircraft, a watercraft or some other vehicle or person in sight.

Question: COM-078 - Distress messages contain...
Option A: information concerning urgent spare parts which are required for a continuation of flight and which have to be ordered in advance.
Option B: information concerning the apron personell and which imply an imminent danger to landing aircraft.
Option C: information concerning the safety of an aircraft, a watercraft or some other vehicle or person in sight.
Option D: information concerning aircraft and their passengers which face a grave and imminent threat and require immediate assistance.
Answer: information concerning aircraft and their passengers which face a grave and imminent threat and require immediate assistance.
